4C30F1166A754D1E8D4D6BE9536B3219.description: install plastic laminate on a countertop core.

1BF3DFDB03244693B1355AFB22AB6B6E.description: build a cabinet from a set of drawings; and

C21A3E26F43742739FB0B3FC45CD9CD7.description: identify and cut the various types of joints used in cabinetmaking;

571DEF3336FB491C8F277115BFB6C9B4.description: recognize the common types of woods used to make cabinets;

D398308154404B2997D628D873DA7D46.description: explain the installation of an island base;

54CCA24A450847E99E9C90637DE9E6F2.description: lay out factory-made cabinets, countertops, and backsplashes;

8C3D4B6AE3C140598BA1BE88D7DA060A.description: identify cabinet components and hardware and describe their purposes;

3EB98F54CED548BE9C7D9B2EC539C514.description: state the classes and sizes of typical base and wall kitchen cabinets;

B7F4DF3C3A9E4A19A589ED29EEF362DD.description: The student selects and installs base and wall cabinets and countertops. The student is expected to:

C9303007FDA34E40848EA6AAC6B48A47.description: estimate the quantities of different trim materials required for selected rooms.

47D353B72F3D4C3B9702EB3BCD1D9F6F.description:
select and use fasteners to install trim, including door trim, window trim, base trim, and
ceiling trim; and

E0E28B09E5B2464F9779139A3FEF4231.description: make coped joint cuts using a coping saw;

CF5DA474B17A43249D0558C1EF465D49.description: make square and miter cuts using a miter box or power miter saw;

3CA4B9E8A8E44CE6996EECA74F2FB034.description: identify the different types of standard moldings and describe their uses;

90EB376935394278A371A260435B8A37.description: The student knows the types of trim used in finish work. The student is expected to:

46BB9F580DD24131B03E74F49246A904.description: sketch the ceiling layout for a basic suspended ceiling; and

AE49CBC2D75549659DE53BEA41B1FCC4.description: interpret plans related to ceiling layout;

E907550952734A50B2908E093E044982.description: identify the different types of suspended ceilings;

640505388226406D94C9B0BE02E6D8F7.description: explain the common terms related to sound waves and acoustical ceiling materials;

F4A6CC1BC6C644ED83116ACFCB5E05BF.description:
The student gains knowledge of the materials, layout, and installation of various types of
suspended ceilings used in commercial construction as well as ceiling tiles, drywall suspension
systems, and pan-type ceilings. The student is expected to:

9F57884977BD48EC85A8B62246BACEE0.description: demonstrate the procedure for placing and hanging a door.

2A0C47A5E29D48C9A928280D9FFD42CA.description: list and identify items included on a typical door schedule; and

9D6192F4E2CD4B29826ED76DC24EA2B0.description:
identify different types of interior door hardware and demonstrate the installation
procedures for them;

FE90CC62BE7C4836A863BB431590F581.description: identify different types of interior doors;

E68AD90ACD58486B8CC0B72E71AC4F7C.description:
demonstrate the installation procedures for placing door jambs and frames in different
types of interior partitions;

5CAF43673E1A48CCA30C509A89548E8D.description: identify various types of door jambs and frames;

CDDF3DAFFFA44FEE9BD602A7837BB070.description:
The student installs metal doors and related hardware in steel-framed, wood-framed, and masonry
walls. The student is expected to:

BF0DCDD4ADC24E89A79CFA50467986E9.description:
identify the correct methods for solving each type of problem that occurs in drywall
finishes; and

A0BCD4B771CB4007969D2DF21F00BC5C.description:
recognize various types of problems that occur in drywall finishes and identify their
causes;

0EC9BE49AE084B13AD2F8B5C61D58A5F.description: identify the automatic tools used in drywall finishing;

8FF968862B13404DAA76394FBBE214B8.description:
identify the hand tools used in drywall finishing and demonstrate the ability to use these
tools;

E7D0BDABF744423697EA3E305AD90EE3.description:
state the differences between the six levels of finish established by industry standards and
distinguish between finish levels by observation;

098A1D74060C4E6880BD33D9EDD78AF1.description:
The student knows the materials, tools, and methods used to finish and patch gypsum drywall. The
student is expected to:

F8CCF33B00074AC19F9C7AB52CF398C1.description: estimate material quantities for a drywall installation.

BE9B0E7BEF284B4A8C894459BA64A235.description: explain how soundproofing is achieved in drywall installations; and

B9AE5AE6D7104C4FB1233AFD04C88ECF.description: install gypsum drywall on steel studs;

8AEB333392424719869B2A184C8A7F8A.description:
perform single-layer and multi-layer drywall installations using different types of
fastening systems, including nails, drywall screws, and adhesives;

6CAA568A97394DDBA4F21A7936248568.description: explain the fastener schedules for different types of drywall installations;

BC3D5835CCAE483B87D14BBDFE7E4063.description: select the type and thickness of drywall required for specific installations;

9C72304A97BF4F2D901F59A7B215D202.description: identify the different types of drywall and their uses;

694DB481B7614F35AF144FF44EF935A2.description:
The student knows various types of gypsum drywall and their uses and the fastening devices and
methods used to install them. The student is expect to:

EE6E77A0ABB744D9B8C2D232F74FAADD.description:
layout and install a steel-stud, non-structural wall with openings to include bracing and
blocking.

DB11E5121F674EB2B02C38F8715305DA.description:
layout and install a steel stud structural wall with openings to include bracing and
blocking; and

DFE61D76375B4BDCBA92F367D4CBAD8C.description: demonstrate the ability to build back-to-back, box, and L-headers;

B1E560E081834A08AD36B31F107A861B.description: identify applications for steel framing systems;

6841A861F9AD4DFB98494D93BC09BE41.description: identify and select the tools and fasteners used in a steel framing system;

6E94CFB72DF44727B393D304AB63E4F4.description: identify the components of a steel framing system;

F35B0F79C1BA40D59DA68B8DFA07C4ED.description:
The student knows the types and grades of steel framing materials and the process for installing
metal framing for interior walls, exterior nonbearing walls, and partitions. The student is expected
to:

E5016E1196634C7EB44BDA6D1F5A1231.description: install three types of siding commonly used in the local area.

0B79649FCB414CAB9311CDA07F057C9F.description: describe the types and applications of stucco and masonry veneer finishes; and

D6AF75F5F4284FDAA983923436B8DE73.description: describe the types and styles of vinyl and metal siding;

69E50ED1BC594E9A8738DE7F22B0B9F0.description: describe fiber-cement siding and its uses;

E4B65E5127FA4DBAA47B0DDC4DBDC2E1.description: describe the types and applications of common wood siding;

C72ABD3731BB49B1A0A83E0CDD2A0D1D.description: demonstrate lap and panel siding estimating methods;

8C264E9D7FF2496AA69FBF555EEA2DD3.description: describe the purpose of wall insulation and flashing;

23F0E543BDDB4CCA94DAFD2BA952433B.description:
The student learns the processes to install various exterior siding materials. The student is
expected to:

EBDF694487FD435FB15B760B55F12B78.description: describe air infiltration control requirements; and

B64F7070AF05474B9620B18D711F1E9F.description: describe the requirements for moisture control and ventilation;

9BE09D58A7DB419B892B893C5580A3E5.description: calculate the required amounts of insulation for a structure;

AB75235C19CF4E6FB2C167AF3DD1452D.description: describe the characteristics of various types of insulation material;

07D95413EFF740B3A3D6124DD022C04F.description:
The student selects and installs various types of insulation in walls, floors, and attics. The student
is expected to:

15E53768DCFF421091CEC31ACA2F88C2.description: demonstrate the techniques for installing other selected types of roofing materials.

E0E557E52E1349F185A6F2AED814D998.description:
complete the cuts and install the main and hip ridge caps using wood shakes or shingles;
and

A0031429422144CD8E1A28C1423C08DD.description: describe how to close up a valley using wood shingles and shakes;

65EEEDBACA2B4260A89AF275461F101F.description: install wood shingles and shakes on roofs;

E4970EDE0004454D8AEC3EC5D5D5A8CF.description: lay out, cut, and install a cricket or saddle;

17042C19D6D64AEAA018839FAB8641CB.description: complete the proper cuts and install the main and hip ridge caps using fiberglass shingles;

00A99BF7135F48B7B68EC0E17020F8DD.description: explain how to make various roof projections watertight when using fiberglass shingles;

4E9E6683ECA947B4AF1C2C2778D2FFF0.description: close up a valley using fiberglass shingles;

41EC922AC6F4457F9F33C91D6F92648B.description: install fiberglass shingles on gable and hip roofs;

0A2F6289C8234F70AAE4288A1C65175F.description: explain the safety requirements for roof jobs;

3D846E527CDA4B09BB876F2F6D15BD46.description: identify the materials and methods used in roofing;

C11098FAD8A846F4B4C063D0EE7F10A9.description:
The student selects and installs common roofing materials for residential and light commercial
projects. The student is expected to:

3BB27A7233BD4354A6A7CF4A2EC4407F.description: calculate the floor area of each room in a floor plan.

5FB6D6232622494593BB769E486DABE4.description:
explain basic construction details and concepts employed in commercial construction;
and

B37735318D5F428F9D84D40C713FEAF6.description: identify and document specific items from a door and window schedule;

3673DB12168D4963AAA0EF7301E9C773.description: accurately read a set of commercial drawings;

78C73679E98B4A3C9689B2A7D65E6F0F.description:
identify the basic keys, abbreviations, and other references contained in a set of
commercial drawings;

41BD5CF15EE042D1B1CD6D92E30A995E.description: recognize the difference between commercial and residential construction drawings;

A1CEEB98A7A54921BD0A6A557B314162.description:
The student is provided with the knowledge to interpret various types of working drawings as they
pertain to commercial construction. The student is expected to:

39FC1A23BC1A4C7B919F404DDC55EF2E.description: recognize workplace issues such as sexual harassment, stress, and substance abuse.

0F095CDD05FA4A2C94A1A461BCAFB0F1.description: explain common uses for computers in the construction industry;

D0068F019333481D954D4D8436ABE2B5.description: demonstrate knowledge of basic computer systems;

EA5B4868A63342BB87BAE7AE9733380D.description: demonstrate the ability to solve problems using critical-thinking skills;

675FD25A15A14EEA96671C3278B8009E.description: explain the role of an employee in the construction industry;

CAFC8B9B0C594374A378979A3C5A02B2.description:
The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and
industry. The student is expected to:

D3539D931D3F4EBF8C9A2BF49BF92B7F.description:
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those
containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

3006381A6B124CDEB21D4CA3876D13EA.description:
Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and
technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

7803CA8D5A3C42F4863E4133E4C15F34.description:
In Construction Technology II, students will gain advanced knowledge and skills needed to enter
the workforce as carpenters, building maintenance technicians, or supervisors or to prepare for a
postsecondary degree in construction management, architecture, or engineering. Students will
build on the knowledge base from Construction Technology I and are introduced to exterior and
interior finish out skills. For safety and liability considerations, limiting course enrollment to 15
students is recommended.

C27802FECAFE404EB43396D7B0EFCBD1.description:
The Architecture and Construction Career Cluster focuses on designing, planning, managing,
building, and maintaining the built environment.

BB1D7908C6A74ECB91E83E49782EFB0A.description:
Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic
standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and
succeed in current or emerging professions.

2F8A6E9EE0634F219B5B8649A86F99AC.description:
General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 11 and 12. Prerequisite:
Construction Technology I. Students shall be awarded two credits for successful completion of this course.
